## The Mystery of the Disappearing Data

Have you ever opened a dataset you worked on a few months ago, only to find that you have no idea where it came from, what the columns mean, or what transformations you applied to it? It's a common experience for data scientists, and it highlights the importance of **data provenance**.

Data provenance is the story of your data. It's the who, what, when, where, and why of your data's journey from its raw form to its current state. It's the secret life of your data, and understanding it is crucial for doing good science.

## A Tale of Two Economists and a Spreadsheet Error

![](https://images.theconversation.com/files/22721/original/8t83k4q5-1366606880.jpg?ixlib=rb-4.1.0&rect=0%2C596%2C4288%2C2086&q=45&auto=format&w=1356&h=668&fit=crop)

In 2010, two Harvard economists, Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff, published a paper called "Growth in a Time of Debt." The paper argued that countries with high levels of government debt tend to have lower economic growth. The paper was incredibly influential and was used to justify austerity policies in countries around the world.

But there was a problem. In 2013, a graduate student named Thomas Herndon tried to reproduce Reinhart and Rogoff's results, and he couldn't. He eventually got a copy of their original spreadsheet and found a simple error: they had accidentally excluded the first five countries from their analysis. When Herndon corrected the error, the main result of the paper disappeared.

This story is a powerful reminder of why data provenance is so important. Without a clear record of how the data was processed, it's easy for errors to creep in and for those errors to have a huge impact.

See the [full story](https://theconversation.com/the-reinhart-rogoff-error-or-how-not-to-excel-at-economics-13646) for more details.

## The Data Detective's Toolkit

So, how do you become a data detective and keep track of your data's provenance? Here are a few tools and techniques:

-   **Lab Notebooks**: Keep a detailed record of your work in a lab notebook (physical or digital). This should include where you got your data, what you did to it, and why you did it.
-   **Scripting**: Use scripts (e.g., Python, R) to process your data. Your scripts are a form of documentation that can be version controlled.
-   **Workflow Management Tools**: For complex projects, use tools like [Snakemake](https://snakemake.readthedocs.io/en/stable/) or [Nextflow](https://www.nextflow.io/) to define and manage your data analysis pipelines. These tools automatically track the provenance of your data.

By embracing the principles of data provenance, you can become a more effective and reproducible data scientist. You'll be able to trust your own results, and others will be able to trust them too.
